displayed_text:
Family Member: He’s at M___ because I worked there. Doctor: That used to be C____> Family Member: Yeah. Patient: Mm,hmm. Family Member: Mm, hmm. Doctor: Will you make your own appointment with him? Family Member: I can. I mean whatever I need to do, just let me know. I’ll do it. (pause) Doctor: Yeah um. Do you want to talk to him soon?
FAM Probably. I know you don’t necessarily start soon. Family Member: Um hum. Doctor: In terms of getting hormone therapy do you want to do it with us? He could do it too. Family Member: Oh, well, he only has to come in how often for that? Doctor: The most common way is once every three months. Family Member: Okay.

Family Member: No, he didn’t fast. Patient: No, I didn’t. Family Member: He had a donut. Doctor: Yeah, there you go. Patient: It was really good. Doctor: Good. Family Member: So a donut sends your sugar up to three hundred. So you know that. Doctor: Everything else is good. Patient: So does Raisin Bran Doctor: Okay. So, I will see you in April. Hopefully, not sooner, if anyone in your family has questions about this, you can direct them to me, and I can potentially hook them up with--- Family Member: Do you have, uh, a nurse that helps you do this stuff or do we just – Doctor: Ehhh. Just call me, and I will find somebody.

Patient: This was more down in the sacroiliac. Doctor: Yes, uh hum. Patient: Uh and there’s a – he injected the left and right both. Doctor: That’s where he injected it. Both sides, okay. Family Member: Yes. Patient: Both sides, and - Doctor: All right. Patient: Yeah. Healthcare Professional: Still having constipation issues? Come and go? Patient: Of course (chuckles) Doctor: Okay, so with the chemo now, the things to keep track of any kind of fevers, infections, anything I need to know right away. Family Member: Yes.

Family Member: So what is – can he take anything to help him sleep? Like natural? Doctor: You can try melatonin. Family Member: Melatonin. That’s right. Doctor: I suggest stop drinking at seven p.m. and you’ll be a miracle. You won’t even get up that much. Patient: Okay. Doctor: Then you’ll say, oh, my, gosh, I’m awake and I didn’t get up. Patient: I’ll go with that line of action first. Doctor: And then you’re going to say, boy, that doctor, she’s really smart. (Laughter) Doctor: Yeah. Yeah. Be sure you don’t like, you know, sleep so hard that you forget to pee if you actually have to pee. Doctor: I’m just saying seven p.m. Okay. Bye. Patient: Okay. So I got – she took – oh, I do, right here. Doctor: You do have sheet to go.

Patient: Okay. Doctor: Remember that? Patient: Right. Doctor: And we stopped the Casodex, correct? Patient: Right. Doctor: You’ve been off of it. Patient: Yes. Just Lupron Doctor: And, today, did you get blood drawn? Patient: Yes. Doctor: Okay, because I haven’t seen that PSA. Healthcare Professional: don’t have a PSA. Doctor: How long ago was it? Healthcare Professional: How long ago, I haven’t checked with

Patient: Okay. Doctor: Um. So, let’s go to the data. You are on therapy, really tolerating it okay? Patient: Mm, hmm. Doctor: And I would say, no worse for the wear? Patient: Nope. Doctor: Um, we have scans that are sort of trending worse but nothing definitively worse --- by new other than the adrenal thing, and that is hedging. Patient: Okay. Doctor: Okay? And then, you have your PSA which is thirteen down to four point nine at your lowest, and back up to ten. Patient: Right. Doctor: Um. (pause) Patient: Okay. Doctor: Um. (pause) Patient: Okay.

Patient: Yeah, yeah, yeah. More information is always better. Doctor: Yeah, yeah. Family Member: We will be…I mean it’s hard to tell at this point, but would we be coming back basically the same day? Or no? Doctor: Uh when for uh typically. Family Member: Tuesdays work really well for me because… Doctor: We’ll try and keep it. Family Member: …it’s dead quiet on Tuesday’s you know so that works out real well. But - Doctor: Perfect. Family Member: Obviously if it doesn’t work that way then we’ll just have to deal with it. Doctor: We’ll work around your schedule for that. Once we plan what study, then absolutely. Family Member: Yeah. Doctor: As far as possible, I prefer Tuesday’s too so I would try and keep you on that. Family Member: Okay.

Patient: Uh huh. Doctor: But we’ll be talking to you within the next few days and seeing if we have to alter the plans at all. Patient: Okay. Doctor: Okay? Patient: So what you think my tests might be? Doctor: Yeah. We’ll find out by tomorrow. Patient: Okay, that’ll be good. Doctor: Okay. Patient: Thank you. Doctor: You’re welcome. Patient: Nice seeing you again. Doctor: Do you have any questions? Patient: Um no. I’m I’m good.

Patient: Um, hum. Doctor: but you really want to go for the home run. So we do not have a home run. We all know that by now. We have patients on this study where um they get the same drug you’ve got or the same dose – Patient: Um, hum. Doctor: - and their PSA drops by ninety-eight percent in the first two months. We’ve seen that. You’re not one of those guys. Patient: Okay. Doctor: We also have other people where the PSA continues to increase at the same pace or in some people it even speeds up. So you’re not in that category either. Then we have some people where the PSA you know slows down, they stay on the drug for anywhere between four to six months. It’s probably doing something, but it’s not know the desired effect or the absolute you know, perfect effect that we expected, so it’s sort of a middle ground, and yet it’s hard to justify you know to keep going if all you’re seeing is like a lukewarm type of response. Patient: Right, right, right. Doctor: So um I I think the time has come uh to uh stop this study and potentially switch gears. Patient: Okay. Doctor: Um there’s two primary reasons for that. One is um PSA level has now increased by more than double - Patient: Yes. Doctor: - compared to the first one; call that the baseline number. So the trial was designed in such a way - because we don’t want to be giving people an experimental therapy and harming them by delaying improving therapy. So the trial was designed in such a way that it was built with a safety check. And the safety check is if the PSA goes up by twofold, then, in other words, a one hundred percent increase from baseline, then patient will come off study. So you have now crossed that threshold. Patient: Uh hum.

Patient: So that, so that’ll cover that. Doctor: Yes. Patient: Do I still get the prune juice and all that shit or not? Doctor: If you – well, you may not need it. Patient: I may not need it. Okay. Okay. So, we’ll just try the pills first. Doctor: Yes. And then you keep goin’ with your pain medicine – Patient: Keep goin’ with my pain medicine – Doctor: Take that as you need it. Patient: Okay. Doctor: Alright. Patient: And then – so we got that out of the way. Doctor: Got that out of the way.

Family Member: Right. Doctor: Not with Dr. S_. Patient: I’m not going to get more radi— Doctor: So, you don’t necessarily need to keep seeing him. Patient: Okay. Doctor: Um. Just Patient: I think that’s probably his standard of care that he has to follow up, but if you’re following up - Doctor: Well, I would keep the appointment with him in January. Patient: Okay. Doctor: And, then, maybe after that I could see you in April and if it turns out in January, your PSA has, you know, gone - instead of continuing to go south, it’s gone north, or we may, we may need to switch treatments whatever, then I would, I would maybe see you sooner to discuss that. Patient: Yeah. Doctor: So, I, why don’t I - I’m going to make the appointment, I think, part of this appointment this January and, uh, I’m not sure if he’s doing the six-month injection, but, um, I’ll make an appointment for, it’s says April sixteenth. I’ll just make it April seventeenth which is a Tuesday. And, you don’t have to see him; you just see me.

Family Member: Okay. Doctor: I think she has to get it improved from you insurance company and then you could come back in a week or two and get it. Patient: Okay. Family Member: Okay. Doctor: And then you’ll have a consult. Family Member: Mm,hmm. Doctor: And then you’ll come back and see me a week after the first injection, I mean a month after the first injection. Patient: Okay. Doctor: At that time you could let us know if you want the twelve month implant or if you want to go with the three month shot. And then we do this for about two years or so and then we stop hormone therapy. By that time you’re done with radiation therapy. Patient: Right. Doctor: And then we wait and see what happens. Hopefully the PSA stays low. Family Member: But during that whole two years you don’t really know what’s going on because you can’t measure it accurately right?
DOC Because the hormone therapy is suppressing what’s there and killing off ninety nine percent of it, then maybe not that last one percent, maybe, maybe not, the radiation does that. So we’re giving you all that we got. Um hum. Um hum. We want it all. Okay. Um and leakage issue. I think he’s doing pretty good, but how long does that typically take?
DOC About another month or so. A lot of times people get better suddenly.

Family Member: Okay Doctor: Okay, so that means that because your prostate is out, we know that the PSA is coming from the cancer, but there's not so much of it that we can see it, so it's there somewhere we just don't know exactly where it is. That, you got radiation for back in 2007 because usually, when prostate cancer recurs, it first recurs near the prostate. Am I making sense so far? Patient: Yeah. Doctor: Okay. Then if it progresses, if you do nothing, you get metastatic disease. And that's when we can see the cancer somewhere in your body either on the CAT scan or the bone scan. So that's a CT or CAT scan or the bone scan because prostate cancer goes to the bone. So when you came to me you already had surgery for localized disease, you had already had radiation, which we sometimes use for our chemical occurrence- Patient: Mm. DOC- but you still had a rising PSA and we weren't sure if you were in this biochemical recurrence bucket or in this metastatic disease bucket. Okay. So, your imaging findings, so your CAT scan here shows…so here are the, this is the summary. I’ll just write summary. We can go through this. So, what this report shows- this is a CAT scan that shows coronary artery calcification, that means there's calcium build up in your around your heart. It's not uncommon for someone your age. Small atrial hernia not important. A thyroid nodule not that important. At some point, we can do a thyroid ultrasound, but we don't need to do anything about that right this moment. So this is what- is is maybe means that it's prostate cancer a small enhancing nodule in the left prostatectomy bed, which may reflect recurrence. So when you look in the full report, what they say is that there is a it's less than once every here is 0.7 by 0.9 centimeters, so then that's like less than one centimeter. So when it's that small, it's like, really difficult. It's actually like impossible to characterize it to say like, yes, this is definitively cancer or this is not cancer. Family Member: Mhm. Doctor: So that's why it says maybe, but they don't- notably, they don't see any anywhere else, okay. So then today you had your bone scan and the bone scans in shows no evidence of metastatic disease. Okay so these are your two summaries. Family Member: Mm. Doctor: So this is CT scan and this is bone scan. Okay. So those are you for your information. So with, with that you really fit into the bucket of what we consider biochemical recurrence. Family Member: Mhm. Doctor: Okay, which is good. Now the question becomes what do we do with you cuz you're in this bucket, biochemical recurrence. So you have a PSA that's rising the cancer somewhere, it seems to be growing, albeit maybe not that fast and before it gets to somewhere to metastatic what do we, what do we do? Okay, so the options for treatment at this point, are 1- observation- and observation what that entails is just monitoring your PSA and periodically doing CAT scans and bone scans and waiting to see if when you develop metastatic disease. Patient: Mm.

Patient: I think so. Doctor: On that one? Patient: Right, but the ones do you remember… Doctor: Yeah, yeah, but those though they don’t agree with you huh? The effects are… Patient: Yeah, the ones you gave me before that I think it was for… Doctor: The Megnace. Patient: Yeah I think that was for you know for throwing up or something like that. I take them because I took them and then it always worked. Like when I be feeling like nauseous I’ll throw up, I’ll take one of them and then I I cool down. But them other ones they Doctor: They didn’t agree with you. Patient: They made me want to jump out of my skin and run up the street. Doctor: That’s too bad, yeah. That’s scary. Doctor: Okay, so let’s give him then Patient: Wooh. Healthcare Professional: So

Patient: Right. Doctor: We do, speaking of trials, we do have a trial coming up. It’s not open yet. But it’s probably going to be a trial after, uh, uh, actually, let me, let me take a step back. The other trial I didn’t tell you. We do have one other trial, uh, that involves, uh, a combination of two things. Uh, one is called, radium. And radium is a radioactive element that looks like calcium. Patient: Um hum. Doctor: And the idea is we can trick the cancer, because prostate cancer is making, stimulating the bone to make new bone. (Sound Door opens) Patient: Um hum. Doctor: So we give this radium that looks like calcium, so he gets put in there also, and can give radiation kind of focally. So where there’s spots on the bone, it gives radiation, but it doesn’t radiate the liver or the lung. Patient: Right. Right. Doctor: So that drug, uh, would be another possible option, because it’s a, it’s an approved drug. I tend to use it in men who have more pain. Patient: Um hum. Doctor: Have, you know, multiple bone spots. Patient: Um hum. Doctor: But, right now, we’re doing a trial where we’re giving that drug in combination with a vaccine. The vaccine is called, sipuleucel-T. And that’s the only vaccine we have for any cancer. Both drugs together have shown that they can improve, uh, how long men live with, from prostate cancer. Patient: Um hum.

Thank you for your valuable contributions to our study! Our goal is to understand how doctors can communicate better with patients by looking at different perceptions of the doctors’ qualities. Understanding your personal experiences with the medical system will help us to contextualize your responses. We invite you to share insights by answering the following questions. Your answers to these questions are strictly confidential and anonymous.

About how long has it been since you las.Within the past year (anytime less than: About how long has it been since you last saw a doctor or other health professional about your health?:::Within the past year (anytime less than 12 months ago)

During the past 12 months, not counting.4 times: During the past 12 months, not counting times you went to an emergency room, how many times did you go to a doctor, nurse, or other health professional to get care for yourself?:::4 times

Sometimes doctors care more about what i.agree: Sometimes doctors care more about what is convenient for them than about their patients' medical needs.:::agree

Doctors are extremely thorough and caref.neutral: Doctors are extremely thorough and careful.:::neutral

You completely trust doctors' decisions.neutral: You completely trust doctors' decisions about which medical treatments are best.:::neutral

A doctor would never mislead you about a.neutral: A doctor would never mislead you about anything.:::neutral

All in all, you trust doctors completely.neutral: All in all, you trust doctors completely.:::neutral

People of my ethnic group receive the sa.agree: People of my ethnic group receive the same medical care from doctors and healthcare workers as people from other groups:::agree

People of my ethnic group are treated th.agree: People of my ethnic group are treated the same as people of other groups by doctors and healthcare workers:::agree

Doctors have the best interests of peopl.neutral: Doctors have the best interests of people of my ethnic group in mind:::neutral

Which of the following best describe you.Unemployed for 1 year or more: Which of the following best describe your current occupational status? Mark all that apply.:::Unemployed for 1 year or more

What is the highest grade or level of s.Some college: What is the highest grade or level of schooling you completed?:::Some college

Are you of Hispanic or Latino origin or.No, not Hispanic or Latino: Are you of Hispanic or Latino origin or descent?:::No, not Hispanic or Latino

What race or races do you consider yours.Asian: What race or races do you consider yourself to be?:::Asian
